problem:
Find the matrix $\mathbf{L} = \begin{pmatrix} a & 0 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}$ such that $a > 0,$ $d > 0,$ and
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 0 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & c \\ 0 & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & -6 \\ -6 & 34 \end{pmatrix}.\]
solution:
Multiplying, we get
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 0 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & c \\ 0 & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a^2 & ac \\ ac & c^2 + d^2 \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, $a^2 = 4,$ $ac = -6,$ and $c^2 + d^2 = 34.$  Since $a > 0,$ $a = 2.$  Then $2c = -6,$ so $c = -3.$  Then $9 + d^2 = 34,$ so $d^2 = 25.$  Since $d > 0,$ $d = 5.$  Hence,
\[\mathbf{L} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ -3 & 5 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
gptanswer:
The system of equations is
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 0 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & c \\ 0 & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & -6 \\ -6 & 34 \end{pmatrix}.\]We solve the system by first multiplying the first equation by $-1$ and then adding the two equations together:
\begin{align*}
\begin{pmatrix} a & 0 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & c \\ 0 & d \end{pmatrix} &= - \begin{pmatrix} a & 0 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 4 & -6 \\ -6 & 34 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a & c \\ 0 & d \end{pmatrix} \\
&= - \begin{pmatrix} a & 0 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 4 & -6 \\ -6 & 34 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a & c \\ 0 & d \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} a & 0 \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 4 - 6 \\ -6 & 34 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a & c \\ 0 & d \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} a & c \\ 0 & d \end{pmatrix}}.
\end{align*}
